hints_html:
Recall (or review) the definition of the 20th order Taylor polynomial of a function \(p(q)\) at a point \(q = a\) from your text (don’t let the change of notation scare you! In this case, f is p and x is q).

Recall that the second order Taylor polynomial of a function \(p(q)\) at a point \(q = a\) is given by \(T_{20}(x)\) where,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T_{20}(q) = p(a) + p'(a)(q - a) + \frac{1}{2}p''(a)(q-a)^{2} + .. + \frac{1}{20!}p^{(20)}(a)(q-a)^{20}\end{aligned}\]

In our case, \(a=1\) and \(p(q) = e^{3q}\).

However even knowing this, it might not be clear how to proceed - Look at what \(a_{20}\) is in the equation above and try to figure out a pattern to help you compute this value.

The previous hint tells us that

\(\displaystyle a_{20} = \frac{p^{(20)}(1)}{20!}\)

So we need to compute the 20th derivative of \(p(q)\) at the point \(q=1\). Try computing the first few derivatives and seeing if you can figure out the pattern.
hints_latex:
Recall (or review) the definition of the 20th order Taylor polynomial of
a function $p(q)$ at a point $q = a$ from your text (don't let the
change of notation scare you! In this case, \emph{f} is \emph{p} and
\emph{x} is \emph{q}).

The previous hint tells us that

$\displaystyle a_{20} = \frac{p^{(20)}(1)}{20!}$

So we need to compute the 20th derivative of $p(q)$ at the point $q=1$.
Try computing the first few derivatives and seeing if you can figure out
the pattern.
hints_raw:
Recall (or review) the definition of the 20th order Taylor polynomial of a function <math>p(q)</math> at a point <math>q = a</math> from your text (don't let the change of notation scare you! In this case, ''f'' is ''p'' and ''x'' is ''q'').
Recall that the second order Taylor polynomial of a function <math>p(q)</math> at a point <math>q = a</math> is given by <math>T_{20}(x)</math> where,
:<math>
\displaystyle T_{20}(q) = p(a) + p'(a)(q - a) + \frac{1}{2}p''(a)(q-a)^{2} + .. + \frac{1}{20!}p^{(20)}(a)(q-a)^{20}
</math>

In our case, <math> a=1 </math> and <math> p(q) = e^{3q} </math>.

However even knowing this, it might not be clear how to proceed - Look at what <math> a_{20} </math> is in the equation above and try to figure out a pattern to help you compute this value.
The previous hint tells us that

<math>
\displaystyle a_{20} = \frac{p^{(20)}(1)}{20!}
</math>

So we need to compute the 20th derivative of <math> p(q) </math> at the point <math> q=1 </math>. Try computing the first few derivatives and seeing if you can figure out the pattern.
question: 1 (i)
sols_html:
Proceeding as in the hints, we compute the 20th derivative to be

\[\begin{aligned} p'(q) &= 3e^{3q} \\ p''(q) &= 3^{2}e^{3q} \\ p'''(q) &= 3^{3}e^{3q} \\ &\vdots \\ p^{(20)}(q) &= 3^{20}e^{3q} \end{aligned}\]

Now using the second hint, we see that

\(\displaystyle a_{20} = \frac{p^{(20)}(1)}{20!} = \frac{3^{20}e^{3}}{20!}\)

which completes the problem.
sols_latex:
Proceeding as in the hints, we compute the 20th derivative to be

\begin{align*}
p'(q) &= 3e^{3q} \\
p''(q) &= 3^{2}e^{3q} \\
p'''(q) &= 3^{3}e^{3q} \\
&\vdots \\
p^{(20)}(q) &= 3^{20}e^{3q} 
\end{align*}

Now using the second hint, we see that

$\displaystyle a_{20} = \frac{p^{(20)}(1)}{20!} = \frac{3^{20}e^{3}}{20!}$

which completes the problem.
sols_raw:
Proceeding as in the hints, we compute the 20th derivative to be

<math>
\begin{align}
p'(q) &= 3e^{3q} \\
p''(q) &= 3^{2}e^{3q} \\
p'''(q) &= 3^{3}e^{3q} \\
&\vdots \\
p^{(20)}(q) &= 3^{20}e^{3q} \\
\end{align}
</math>

Now using the second hint, we see that

<math> \displaystyle a_{20} = \frac{p^{(20)}(1)}{20!} = \frac{3^{20}e^{3}}{20!}</math>

which completes the problem.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}p(q)=e^{3q}.\end{aligned}\]

Consider its 20th order Taylor polynomial at q=1;

\[\begin{aligned} T_{20}(q)=a_0+a_1(q-1)+a_2(q-1)^2+\dots+a_{20}(q-1)^{20}\end{aligned}\]

What is \(a_{20}\)?
statement_raw:
Let

:<math>
\displaystyle{}p(q)=e^{3q}.
</math>

Consider its 20th order Taylor polynomial at q=1;

:<math>
T_{20}(q)=a_0+a_1(q-1)+a_2(q-1)^2+\dots+a_{20}(q-1)^{20}
</math>

What is <math>a_{20}</math>?
